Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (summary process and housing jurisdiction) and general jurisdiction of the Boston Housing Court over landlord–tenant claims arising in Boston/Housing Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (recognizing landlord obligations regarding habitability)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (recognizing landlord obligations regarding habitability)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that, in residential leases, there is an implied warranty that landlords will provide and maintain premises that are safe, clean, and fit for human habitation, and describes the scope and consequences of breaching that warranty. This expressly recognizes landlord obligations regarding habitability and treats them as contractual duties, making the case a leading authority for that proposition.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will.… Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit.”
